name: Ozoni (Japanese New Year Mochi Soup - Kanto Style)
description: Enjoy hearty Ozoni (Japanese New Year Mochi Soup) for New Year's Day breakfast. This version with clear broth hails from the Kanto region in Eastern Japan. Ozoni is one of the most popular and important dishes of Osechi Ryori or traditional Japanese New Year foods.
recipeIngredient: ¼ tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt ((for the chicken))
4 stalks komatsuna ((3.5 oz, 100 g; or use spinach))

recipeInstructions.text: Before You Start: Please note that this recipe calls for homemade dashi that takes a minimum of 20 minutes to make. Please see my recipe for How to Make Dashi. If you don‘t have time to make this Japanese soup stock from scratch, you can use a dashi packet or dashi powder.
recipeInstructions.name: Before You Start: Please note that this recipe calls for homemade dashi that takes a minimum of 20 minutes to make. Please see my recipe for How to Make Dashi. If you don‘t have time to make this Japanese soup stock from scratch, you can use a dashi packet or dashi powder.

recipeInstructions.text: I recommend prepping this recipe the day before you plan to serve. The next day, reheat the soup and add the mochi just before serving. For more helpful tips on planning your Japanese New Year feast, please read my A 5-Day Osechi Cooking Timeline blog post.

itemListElement.text: Cut 1 chicken thigh into bite-sized pieces (1 inch, 2.5 cm) and put them in a small bowl. Then, add ¼ tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt.

itemListElement.text: Add 1 Tbsp sake and mix well with your hands. Let the chicken marinate for 15 minutes.
itemListElement.name: Add 1 Tbsp sake and mix well with your hands. Let the chicken marinate for 15 minutes.

itemListElement.text: Meanwhile, blanch 4 stalks komatsuna (or spinach) in boiling water and cook until tender (do not overcook). Remove from the pot and soak it in iced water to stop the cooking.

itemListElement.text: Squeeze the water out of the komatsuna and cut it into pieces 1½ inches (3 cm) long. Set aside.
itemListElement.name: Squeeze the water out of the komatsuna and cut it into pieces 1½ inches (3 cm) long. Set aside.

itemListElement.text: Make a knot in the stem of each of 4 sprigs mitsuba (Japanese parsley) (optional). Set aside for garnish. Next, peel 2–3 thick strips of yuzu zest (optional).

itemListElement.text: Flip the pieces over and remove any white pith. Then, slice the strips of yuzu zest into very thin julienned strips. Place on a small dish and set aside to serve as garnish later.

itemListElement.text: Add 4 cups dashi (Japanese soup stock) to a large saucepan or pot and bring it to a boil. Once boiling, add the chicken pieces.
itemListElement.name: Add 4 cups dashi (Japanese soup stock) to a large saucepan or pot and bring it to a boil. Once boiling, add the chicken pieces.

itemListElement.text: Cover to cook for 5–7 minutes, depending on the size of the chicken pieces.
itemListElement.name: Cover to cook for 5–7 minutes, depending on the size of the chicken pieces.

itemListElement.text: Once the chicken is cooked, skim off the foam and fat from the surface of the soup with a fine-mesh strainer.
itemListElement.name: Once the chicken is cooked, skim off the foam and fat from the surface of the soup with a fine-mesh strainer.

itemListElement.text: Add 1 Tbsp sake, 1 Tbsp soy sauce, and 1 tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt. Stir well and keep it covered on a simmer.
itemListElement.name: Add 1 Tbsp sake, 1 Tbsp soy sauce, and 1 tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt. Stir well and keep it covered on a simmer.

itemListElement.text: Once the soup broth and toppings are ready, place 4 pieces Japanese rice cake (mochi) directly on the rack of a toaster oven and toast until puffy. You can also toast the mochi over an open flame, under a broiler, or in a frying pan.

itemListElement.text: Serve the chicken and soup in individual serving bowls. Add one piece of toasted mochi on top of the soup in each bowl. Top with the komatsuna, mitsuba (optional) and yuzu (optional). Enjoy immediately.

itemListElement.text: Remove the mochi and store the leftover soup in an airtight container or in the pot; keep in the refrigerator for up to 3 days. I recommend toasting and adding the mochi to the soup just prior to serving.

review.reviewBody:
I made this ozoni tonight despite being out of season, it was amazing and the broth was great!
You can substitute collard greens instead of komatsuna; it's a little thicker and more bitter but not all too different.

Only thing I'd do differently is maybe use storebought kirimochi next time. I used homemade mochi and they melted in the oven and made a mess everywhere lol. Don't use a wire rack like in the picture!

Hi Nami. I LOVE this recipe. It was my favorite part of our osechi ryori (out of everything! I made 12 different dishes!) This is just perfect. I am very fond of soups with a clear dashi broth and the chicken in this is so soft, the toasted mochi is so delicious, and the yuzu zest adds such perfect flavor. I made the kansai style ozoni last year but I'm afraid to say that kanto style is my favorite by a mile. For me, there is no contest, but I also prefer osuimono to miso soup on a daily basis, so you can see my bias. :9 Also, there is currently a typo step 13 that says "mocha" instead of "mochi", just so you know. Thanks for the recipe!
